# Learning Objectives

1.  Calculate the variance and standard deviation of discrete random
    variables
2.  Calculate the variance of sums of discrete random variables
3.  Calculate the variance of functions of discrete random variables

## What is the expected value of a function?

::: definition
::: def-title
Definition: Expected value of function of RV
:::

::: def-cont
For any function $g$ and discrete r.v. $X$, the expected value of $g(X)$
is $$\mathbb{E}[g(X)] = \sum_{\{all\ x\}}\ g(x) p_X(x).$$
:::
:::

## Variance of a RV

::: definition
::: def-title
Definition: Variance of RV
:::

::: def-cont
The variance of a r.v. $X$, with (finite) expected value
$\mu_X=\mathbb{E}[X]$ is
$$\sigma_X^2=Var(X)=\mathbb{E}[(X-\mu_X)^2] = \mathbb{E}[(X-\mathbb{E}[X])^2]$$
:::
:::

::: definition
::: def-title
Definition: Standard deviation of RV
:::

::: def-cont
The standard deviation of a r.v. $X$ is
$$\sigma_X = SD(X) = \sqrt{\sigma_X^2}=\sqrt{Var(X)}.$$
:::
:::

## Questions {visibility="hidden"}

**Questions:** Why do we square the difference in the variance
definition? $(X-\mu_X)^2$

-   Why not define the measure of spread as
    $\mathbb{E}[X-\mu_X] = \mathbb{E}[X-\mathbb{E}[X]]$?

-   Why not use $\mathbb{E}[|X-\mu_X|]$?

## Let's calculate the variance and prove it!

::: columns
::: {.column width="30%"}
::: proof1
::: proof-title
Lemma 6: "Computation formula" for Variance
:::

::: proof-cont
The variance of a r.v. $X$, can be computed as $$\begin{align}
\sigma_X^2 & =Var(X) \\ & = \mathbb{E}[X^2]-\mu_X^2 \\ & = \mathbb{E}[X^2] - (\mathbb{E}[X])^2
\end{align}$$
:::
:::
:::
:::

# (break) Some Important Variance and Expected Values Results

## Variance of a function with a single RV

::: proof1
::: proof-title
Lemma 7
:::

::: proof-cont
For a r.v. $X$ and constants $a$ and $b$, $$Var(aX+b) = a^2Var(X).$$
:::
:::

Proof will be exercise in homework. It's fun! In a mathy kinda way.

## Important results for ***independent*** RVs

::: theorem
::: thm-title
Theorem 8
:::

::: thm-cont
For independent r.v.'s $X$ and $Y$, and functions $g$ and $h$,
$$\mathbb{E}[g(X)h(Y)] = \mathbb{E}[g(X)]\mathbb{E}[h(Y)].$$
:::
:::

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Corollary 1
:::

::: prop-cont
For independent r.v.'s $X$ and $Y$,
$$\mathbb{E}[XY] = \mathbb{E}[X]\mathbb{E}[Y].$$
:::
:::

## Variance of sum of independent discrete RVs

::: theorem
::: thm-title
Theorem 9: Variance of sum of independent discrete r.v.'s
:::

::: thm-cont
For independent discrete r.v.'s $X_i$ and constants $a_i$,
$i=1,2,\dots, n$,
$$Var\Bigg(\sum_{i=1}^n a_iX_i\Bigg) = \sum_{i=1}^n a_i^2Var(X_i).$$
:::
:::

Simpler version: 

$$Var(a_1 X + a_2 Y) = Var(a_1X) + Var(a_2 Y) = a_1^2 Var(X) + a_2^2 Var(Y)$$

## Corollaries

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Corollary 2
:::

::: prop-cont
For independent discrete r.v.'s $X_i$, $i=1,2,\dots, n$,
$$Var\Bigg(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i\Bigg) = \sum_{i=1}^n Var(X_i).$$
:::
:::

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Corollary 3
:::

::: prop-cont
For independent identically distributed (i.i.d.) discrete r.v.'s $X_i$,
$i=1,2,\dots, n$, $$Var\Bigg(\sum_{i=1}^n X_i\Bigg) = n Var(X_1).$$
:::
:::

## Expected value of a function of a continuous RV

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
**How do we calculate the expected value of a function of a discrete RV
or joint RVs?**

   

For discrete RVs:

$$\mathbb{E}[g(X)] = \sum_{\{all\ x\}}\ g(x) p_X(x).$$
$$\mathbb{E}[g(X, Y)] = \sum_{\{all\ x\}}\sum_{\{all\ y\}}\ g(x,y) p_{X,Y}(x,y).$$
:::

## Important properties of expected values of functions of continuous RVs

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: proposition
::: prop-title
Function of RV with two constants
:::

::: prop-cont
$\mathbb{E}[aX+b] =a\mathbb{E}[X]+b$
:::
:::

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Function of two RVs added
:::

::: prop-cont
$\mathbb{E}[X+Y] =\mathbb{E}[X]+\mathbb{E}[Y]$
:::
:::

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Expected value of sum of independent RVs pt 1
:::

::: prop-cont
If $X_1, X_2, \ldots X_n$ are continuous RVs and $a_1, a_2, \ldots a_n$
are constants, then
$$\mathbb{E}\Bigg[\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i X_i\Bigg] = \sum_{i=1}^{n}a_i\mathbb{E}[X_i]$$
:::
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: proposition
::: prop-title
Expected value of multiplication of function of independent RVs
:::

::: prop-cont
If $X$ and $Y$ are independent continuous RVs, and $g$ and $h$ are
functions, then
$$\mathbb{E}[g(X)h(Y)] =\mathbb{E}[g(X)]\mathbb{E}[h(Y)]$$
:::
:::

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Expected value of multiplication of independent RVs
:::

::: prop-cont
If $X$ and $Y$ are independent continuous RVs, then
$$\mathbb{E}[XY] = \mathbb{E}[X] \mathbb{E}[Y] $$
:::
:::
:::
:::

## Variance of continuous RVs

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
**How do we calculate the variance of a discrete RV?**

   

For discrete RVs:

$$
\begin{align}
Var(X) & =
\mathbb{E}[(X-\mu_X)^2] \\ & = \mathbb{E}[(X-\mathbb{E}[X])^2] \\ &= \mathbb{E}[X^2]-(\mathbb{E}[X])^2 \\ & = \sum_{\{all\ x\}}(x-\mu_x)^2 p_{X}(x)
\end{align}
$$
:::

## Important properties of variances of continuous RVs

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: proposition
::: prop-title
Function of RV with two constants
:::

::: prop-cont
$$Var[aX+b] = a^2Var[X]$$
:::
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: proposition
::: prop-title
Variance of sum of independent RVs pt 1
:::

::: prop-cont
If $X_1, X_2, \ldots X_n$ are independent continuous RVs and
$a_1, a_2, \ldots a_n$ are constants, then
$$Var\Bigg(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_i X_i\Bigg) =\sum_{i=1}^{n} a^2_i Var(X_i)$$
:::
:::

::: proposition
::: prop-title
Variance of sum of independent RVs pt 2
:::

::: prop-cont
If $X_1, X_2, \ldots X_n$ are independent continuous RVs, then
$$Var\Bigg(\sum_{i=1}^{n} X_i\Bigg) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} Var(X_i)$$
:::
:::
:::
:::
